full_transcript:
[7.8s - 10.7s]: Welcome to the YONN Earth Community Podcast.

[11.5s - 16.2s]: Today we are visiting with Jeff Moyer, the CEO of Rodal Institute.

[16.6s - 16.9s]: Hi Jeff.

[18.1s - 19.1s]: Hi Aaron, how are you today?

[19.7s - 20.3s]: I'm doing great.

[20.5s - 21.0s]: How are you doing?

[21.4s - 21.8s]: Good.

[22.1s - 22.7s]: It's much to be here.

[23.4s - 25.6s]: Well I'm really excited for our conversation.

[25.6s - 32.9s]: I know we've got a lot to cover for our audience and before we dive in let me tell them a little

[32.9s - 34.8s]: about you and your background.

[35.9s - 42.0s]: Jeff Moyer is the Chief Executive Officer of Rodal Institute and has been on staff at

[42.0s - 44.4s]: Rodal Institute for over 44 years.

[45.1s - 51.0s]: He spent over 30 years as a farm manager director, was appointed as Executive Director of the

[51.0s - 56.9s]: Institute in September of 2015 and became CEO in September of 2019.

[57.9s - 63.8s]: Jeff was project leader on the highly acclaimed organic no-till project and is the author of

[63.8s - 69.8s]: the book on this subject called Organic No-till Farming, advancing no-till agriculture crops

[69.8s - 71.0s]: soil equipment.

[71.6s - 77.5s]: He is a past chair of the National Organic Standards Board and currently sits on the

[77.5s - 83.3s]: boards of Regenerative Organic Alliance as Board Chair and the Soil Health Institute.

[84.3s - 90.4s]: Jeff is a founding board member of Pennsylvania Certified Organic and past founder and board

[90.4s - 95.1s]: chair of the Seed Farm, a new farmer incubator project.

[95.4s - 102.6s]: So Jeff, wow, just an amazing career that you've had already thus far and I know you have

[102.6s - 108.3s]: a really important perspective to share with our audience and we're going to talk there

[108.3s - 108.6s]: today.

[108.7s - 109.9s]: We're going to get dirty here.

[110.2s - 115.8s]: So let's just dive right in and then want to ask you what's the big deal?

[115.9s - 118.6s]: What's the big deal about soil and regeneration?

[118.6s - 119.9s]: What does this even matter?

[122.2s - 131.2s]: Wow, the whole idea of regenerating the health of the soil is key to our survival as a human

[131.2s - 131.8s]: species.

[132.9s - 140.2s]: You know, we have to go back in time a little bit to really get into the ground and dig

[140.2s - 143.9s]: up the dirt on regeneration and what we're talking about.

[144.4s - 151.4s]: Our founder, J.I. Rodeil, way back in 1942, he wrote some words on a blackboard.

[151.8s - 157.2s]: He said, healthy soil equals healthy food equals healthy people.

[158.0s - 161.1s]: So he was really, you know, I don't know if he was a visionary.

[161.8s - 162.6s]: Some people say he was.

[162.9s - 164.0s]: I don't know if he was a genius.

[164.8s - 165.9s]: I don't know if he was just lucky.

[166.7s - 167.9s]: It doesn't really matter.

[168.1s - 171.7s]: You know, he stumbled on to something that has really captured the attention of people

[172.2s - 180.4s]: as he began to tell us as farmers that our role was not to produce food and it wasn't

[180.4s - 182.7s]: to manage the soil is to make people healthy.

[183.2s - 190.3s]: Now the tools that we use are the soil and the food, but how we manage that, the end

[190.3s - 192.2s]: goal has to be to make people healthy.

[192.7s - 200.3s]: So he would say if the goal, for example, farmers is to kill weeds, then Roundup is a great

[200.3s - 200.6s]: tool.

[201.6s - 205.2s]: But if the goal is to make people healthy, it's a terrible tool.

[206.1s - 208.4s]: There's no way you can use Roundup to make people healthy.

[208.6s - 210.5s]: It just doesn't move you in the right direction.

[211.1s - 219.8s]: So he began to look at and discuss this production paradigm that he called organic agriculture

[220.9s - 224.0s]: and is sort of caught on, but it was moving relatively slowly.

[224.4s - 230.8s]: His son Robert Rodeo took over the, the, the organic, I mean, the, the Rodeo enterprises

[231.6s - 237.7s]: in 1971 when J.R. Rodeo passed away and he was a little frustrated with the speed at

[237.7s - 240.9s]: which organic practices were being adopted.

[241.7s - 246.5s]: So he was an early proponent of sort of giving the standard or creating a standard within

[246.5s - 248.8s]: the federal government and working with the USDA.

[249.9s - 251.7s]: Many people were upset then.

[251.8s - 256.8s]: Many people are still upset, you know, 30 years later that that's what happened with

[256.8s - 262.5s]: the word, but he saw it as an opportunity to move farther and faster because if you had

[262.5s - 268.1s]: a word that is sanctioned by the USDA, certainly it carries a lot more penational marketplace

[268.1s - 270.4s]: than things will move farther faster and they have.

[271.2s - 276.4s]: But he was also pretty smart and he recognized that when you give something away, you lose

[276.4s - 276.8s]: control.

[277.6s - 283.6s]: So we lost control of the word and we gave up a lot of concepts that were originally

[283.6s - 288.1s]: part of organic, for example, the idea of continuous improvement.

[288.7s - 293.2s]: That kind of shelved early on in the conversations with the federal government because they wanted

[293.2s - 300.8s]: to put our organic stand under their marketing division and how does an ag marketer certify

[300.8s - 306.0s]: continuous improvement, you know, it just was too esoteric for a periodical for them to

[306.0s - 306.8s]: dig grass.

[307.2s - 309.0s]: So they put that off on the side.

[309.5s - 314.5s]: There was always this idea of that organic was supposed to be good for the soil.

[315.5s - 319.4s]: And so there's a little bit of language in the law about soil, but it's really not very strong.

[320.7s - 326.0s]: There was always a concept in the organic farming community that dealt with animal welfare.

[326.7s - 331.0s]: But the standards in our NLP program are relatively weak on animal welfare.

[331.7s - 339.2s]: And then the organic standard, the way it's written today in our national NLP regulations,

[339.5s - 344.4s]: national organic program regulations, there's no language all around human health or

[344.4s - 351.7s]: social justice or any of those community kind of activist or activism components.

[352.7s - 360.7s]: And so he was really interested in figuring out how do we magnify the word organic and make it

[360.7s - 364.7s]: mean what it really should mean and embody all of those tools.

[364.8s - 366.7s]: So he came up with the new word regeneration.

[367.7s - 372.3s]: At the time he was talking about that, that was late 1970s, early 1980s.

[372.3s - 377.0s]: He was talking about regenerative agriculture and everybody sort of poo pooed that idea and said,

[377.1s - 382.0s]: no, we're going to really gravitate towards this word sustainable and sustainability.

[383.2s - 386.8s]: The problem with the word sustainability and that's never been a rodeo word.

[387.1s - 389.2s]: It's a relatively weak word.

[389.4s - 391.0s]: It's not a strong action word.

[391.6s - 395.4s]: Now, it's a simple word to understand because people understand what sustain means.

[396.1s - 398.6s]: But you can sustain a bad system with enough inputs.

[399.2s - 406.1s]: And some systems and some processes really should not be sustained because that's not what we

[406.1s - 410.1s]: want to do. So if somebody said, how is your life and you said, oh, it's sustainable,

[410.5s - 415.1s]: they'd be kind of sad or how is your relationship with your spouse or your significant other and you

[415.1s - 421.2s]: said, oh, it's sustainable. Yeah, just like you're smiling and I am too, people chop on

[421.2s - 426.0s]: go, yeah, that's not a good word. I don't want to sustain it. And if you talk to people in the

[426.0s - 431.2s]: international community, particularly people that are struggling financially or struggling with

[431.2s - 434.7s]: their farm operation because they don't have enough inputs to do what they want to do,

[435.3s - 439.2s]: or don't have access to markets. And you say, how would you like to sustain what you have?

[439.3s - 445.1s]: They said, no, we want to improve it. So he's looking for a word that showcased this concept of

[445.1s - 450.5s]: improvement, continuous improvement, and he latched onto the word regenerative. And to me,

[450.6s - 455.8s]: it makes a lot of sense. What we've done now at Road Hill Institute in working with some major

[455.8s - 461.6s]: brand partners is we've linked those two words together. And so now we talk about regenerative

[461.6s - 467.9s]: organic certification, regenerative organic, freefaring practices, because we really believe that

[467.9s - 473.0s]: organic is a baseline by which we really should be farming to get the chemistry and the synthetic

[473.0s - 477.3s]: chemicals out of our food production system. Going back to that original paradigm, trying to make

[477.3s - 482.6s]: people healthy, we've got to get those chemicals out of the system. And then we can launch from

[482.6s - 487.8s]: there into a regenerative model where we really do include animal welfare, social justice,

[488.2s - 496.2s]: and then of course, focusing on healthy soil. Absolutely. Yeah, that is such an important and

[496.2s - 505.1s]: central discussion that affects all of us. And one of the things I noticed when we're doing the

[505.1s - 512.1s]: Y on Earth work and events all around the country is that a lot of folks still have this impression

[512.1s - 518.1s]: that organic agriculture somehow does a new thing or even a fat or some sort of marketing

[518.8s - 524.6s]: invention. And so I often have a lot of fun on a stage going clear to one end and saying let's

[524.6s - 529.3s]: create a timeline and start maybe with the Egyptian empire and walk our way back through a few

[529.3s - 536.0s]: thousand years of history, all of which basically was organic agriculture right up until about a

[536.0s - 543.2s]: century ago. And what I think is so important for folks to understand, to really understand,

[543.7s - 550.4s]: is that this chemical and synthetic form of agriculture is the aberration. It is the

[551.4s - 559.7s]: thing that is absolutely outside of the norm of how we ordinarily tend to do agriculture as a species.

[560.4s - 568.4s]: And I wonder if you come into that sort of encounter with folks, you know, not really understanding

[568.4s - 576.3s]: the context the way it needs to be understood. Well, we certainly we do. I would say that the timeline

[577.0s - 584.9s]: that you defined is exactly correct. The current industrial agricultural model that we have in place,

[585.1s - 588.7s]: not just the United States but globally around the world is a relatively new phenomenon

[589.3s - 596.6s]: that was really designed around this concept that what we need to do is focus all of our energy

[596.6s - 604.7s]: on tons of output. We focus very little on true quality. Now every farmer wants to produce a

[604.7s - 610.1s]: quality product and I'm not suggesting they don't want to do that. But the measuring stick by which

[610.1s - 616.3s]: we judge success on farms or that we incentivize farmers to operate is based on yield.

[617.9s - 626.6s]: It's a little dissonuous to suggest that the true sum of our of our ability to survive on the

[626.6s - 632.8s]: planet comes down to tons and tons of commodities. Obviously we have to produce food because we have

[632.8s - 637.5s]: billions of people to feed and I'm not suggesting that that's not important. But it's not the sole

[637.5s - 643.0s]: measuring stick. We should not say, well, farmers are judged only on their ability to produce tons and

[643.0s - 647.9s]: tons of this yellow stuff that we call corn and they don't even see it as producing food. Most of

[647.9s - 652.1s]: the farmers across the Midwestern part of the United States don't really see themselves as food

[652.1s - 656.9s]: producers. They're commodity growers. They grow commodities of corn and beans. The corn could be

[656.9s - 662.2s]: used for ethanol. It could go. There's probably corn in this vast. I have no idea. There's corn and

[662.2s - 668.1s]: soy beans in everything. And so they don't really see themselves as food producers. Well, when we

[668.1s - 676.9s]: separate the concept of agriculture from food production, we've disincentivized farmers from

[676.9s - 683.3s]: paying attention to what their real goal is. And then at the same time, what we've done is we've

[683.3s - 691.3s]: said we're willing to sacrifice our soil and our environment and our ecology for the sake of that

[691.3s - 696.9s]: yield. So it doesn't matter what you do to the soil. Farmers aren't judged on that. Do whatever

[696.9s - 701.6s]: you have to do. Get as many tons as you can, produce them as cheaply as you can, and try to survive

[701.6s - 708.2s]: on the margins. And that's really an unfair system. Farmers have always done what we've asked

[708.2s - 714.3s]: them to do. And unfortunately, we've asked them to do the wrong thing. Now, where I disagree with

[714.3s - 719.5s]: the timeline is that when we look at organic agriculture or regenerative organic agriculture today,

[720.1s - 725.8s]: what we do look at the past to see what farmers did that was good, we've also modernized it.

[725.8s - 736.0s]: So when we pay attention to modern engineering, we pay attention to modern biology. So we're using

[736.6s - 743.9s]: good plant genetics. We're not suggesting that what we do is go back in time and put a few million

[743.9s - 749.5s]: bison on the great plains for a few people who come out there to manage them and say that's organic

[749.5s - 753.8s]: agriculture, that's where we should head. That's not the direction we're heading. We're going to

[753.8s - 759.9s]: take advantage of precision agriculture. We're going to take advantage of robotics. We're going to

[759.9s - 766.3s]: take advantage of all the tools that are at our disposal. So long as they don't interfere with

[766.3s - 772.1s]: our ability to make people healthy. So those tools that we've incorporated in agriculture that don't

[772.1s - 776.0s]: lend themselves to human health, we're going to sit on the shelf and say they no longer have a

[776.0s - 781.3s]: role to play in food production. It's more fiber production because they're destroying the soil,

[781.3s - 787.1s]: they're destroying the animals and the biodiversity on that, that live in that environment and

[787.1s - 793.7s]: ecology. And then we're also unfortunately making ourselves sick. And that's kind of where we're

[793.7s - 802.4s]: stocking. We understand that there's big business that's pushing the current model. And there's a

[802.4s - 809.7s]: lot of incentive out there in the business world to keep the status quo going. Change is expensive,

[809.7s - 815.0s]: change is difficult. Even positive change can be challenging and difficult. We understand that. You

[815.4s - 820.8s]: graduate from high school, you go to college, positive change, still struggle, there's tension,

[821.0s - 825.9s]: we understand that. You're single, you get married, tension. We understand that. It's a positive

[825.9s - 829.9s]: change. Well, the same thing happens when you move from a chemical-based system to an organic system.

[830.5s - 835.8s]: There's stresses in there. What we need to do now is a society is figure out, certainly we

[835.8s - 839.9s]: have to agree that that's where we want to go. And if we do agree with that, then we have to work

[839.9s - 845.4s]: with those producers and farmers out there in the countryside and ranchers and say, how can we

[845.4s - 852.6s]: help you navigate this tumultuous transition period? Yeah. You know, one of the things that you're

[853.7s - 860.4s]: spearheading and innovating on is the regenerative organic certification program that's in the process

[860.4s - 867.8s]: of being rolled out this year, 2020. And I am so thrilled with my own personal background in the

[867.8s - 873.8s]: Food and Agriculture arena for many, many years. I am so thrilled about this step that we're now

[873.8s - 881.9s]: taking and about the both opportunity and imperative for us as consumers to do really all that we

[881.9s - 888.4s]: can do to support with our dollars for those food purchases, those beverage purchases, those fiber

[888.4s - 896.3s]: clothing purchases, as much of this emerging regenerative organic certified method of production

[896.3s - 903.3s]: as we can. And I'm thrilled to dive into that and really to share that as a very hopeful and

[903.3s - 910.4s]: groundbreaking, you know, no pun intended development that's underway as we speak. And I want to

[910.4s - 914.7s]: hear from you. What are you excited about? What are the challenges? And how does the general public

[914.7s - 921.8s]: fit into helping this thing move forward as quickly as possible? Well, I'm glad you brought up

[921.8s - 928.2s]: the model that we're creating around regenerative organic certification and the alliance that we

[928.2s - 933.5s]: built to move that model forward. It's a real exciting time. I mean, one of the things that

[933.5s - 939.3s]: Road to the Institute prides itself on is that we are a solutions-based company. There are a lot

[939.3s - 946.0s]: of organizations out there non-profits, activist groups that are really, really good at pointing out

[946.0s - 954.2s]: problems. We tend to be really, really good at pointing out solutions. That's what we're all about.

[954.9s - 960.5s]: You know, we don't want to sit here and say, you know, it's easy to say, round up is bad. Okay,

[960.6s - 964.5s]: what's the alternative? How do we give people solutions to work around that? That's what Road to

[964.5s - 969.1s]: Health is all about. The other thing we're really good at is putting science around this story.

[969.5s - 976.1s]: We are a science-based organization that focuses on soil, soil health, and food production

[976.9s - 984.0s]: with an end goal of having healthy populations. So we see ourselves really as a human health

[984.0s - 989.8s]: organization, although we work in the soil. So it seems a little odd, but I was meeting with a

[990.7s - 996.3s]: cardiologist yesterday that was talking about heart health and how he traced the heart health

[996.3s - 1001.9s]: back to dental health, which traced back to breathing. And he said, but at the end of the day,

[1002.4s - 1009.1s]: heart health steps with how farmers treat the soil. And you know, it was an enlightening moment for

[1009.1s - 1015.4s]: him when he came to that conclusion that he said, what I really need to do is get people to eat a

[1015.4s - 1020.0s]: healthy organic diet. Of course, they need some exercise. That's part of heart health. But he said,

[1020.2s - 1025.5s]: if they don't feed themselves properly, and if we don't take care of the soil properly,

[1025.8s - 1031.8s]: it's impossible for people to have human health. So that's really an amazing link that we've been

[1031.8s - 1037.8s]: able to make through this scientific enterprise that Road to Institute saw about. Now, what we've

[1037.8s - 1044.9s]: done is we've tried to create a certification model so that we can bring customers, consumers,

[1044.9s - 1050.5s]: and the average person into this dialogue. Because as you've just alluded to, we all vote with our

[1050.5s - 1059.6s]: dollars for a particular food production system. We vote sometimes three for five times a day. It

[1059.6s - 1065.7s]: depends on your eating habits. But we vote constantly with our dollars. And people aren't really

[1065.7s - 1071.4s]: always paying attention or aware of what they're doing with those food dollars. So what we've

[1071.4s - 1076.2s]: done is we've partnered with a bunch of brands that produce food and fiber products and said, how do

[1076.2s - 1083.8s]: we orchestrate a new certification system that consumers can rally around so that they can

[1084.4s - 1089.6s]: purchase products that incorporate a whole suite of values that they come to the marketplace with.

[1090.2s - 1095.5s]: Most customers or consumers come to a grocery store, a restaurant, or wherever they purchase

[1095.5s - 1100.8s]: their food or if you're buying fiber products. You come with a suite of values, not just one.

[1101.3s - 1106.8s]: Some people are single issue voters. Most people have a whole suite of issues that are of concern to

[1106.8s - 1113.6s]: them. Same thing is true in the marketplace. So for example, one of our concerns was if somebody wants

[1113.6s - 1119.5s]: to come and buy a product that is organic, that's great. But somebody else may come and say, well,

[1119.5s - 1124.8s]: I'm really interested in social justice. So I'm looking for a product that addresses my social

[1124.8s - 1130.7s]: justice concerns. And then we have people that say, why can't I have both? Why can't I have a product

[1130.7s - 1137.5s]: that both embodies my values around getting the chemicals out of the system and having an

[1137.5s - 1143.4s]: organically certified product as well as a product that has a social justice component to it.

[1143.6s - 1148.2s]: Or an animal welfare component or carbon sequestration because the climate is really important to me.

[1148.7s - 1154.8s]: Why can't I have all of that? We believe you can. And you should and people deserve that. And that's

[1154.8s - 1160.9s]: the rallying cry around which we hope consumers begin to focus as we roll out our regenerative

[1160.9s - 1166.0s]: organic certification and seal. You know, I've talked with a farmer. I just I'm pretty I like to

[1166.0s - 1171.4s]: deal with visuals because I'm a visual person. And this farmer said to me, I feel like a boy scout

[1172.1s - 1178.0s]: with a slash full of merit badges because I have so many logos on my product that I'm trying to sell

[1178.0s - 1183.8s]: because I am animal welfare approved. And I got a social justice label and I've got an organic

[1183.8s - 1189.3s]: seal and I'm I'm Hualal and I'm you know, kosher and I'm all these things. He said, couldn't I just

[1189.3s - 1194.8s]: find, you know, to continue with that boy scout's theme, he said, you know, when you get enough merit

[1194.8s - 1200.1s]: badges, you become an Eagle Scout. And that's the only merit badge you use. You just showed everybody,

[1200.3s - 1204.9s]: oh, I'm an Eagle Scout. And people, even if they weren't in scouting, they recognized that it took

[1204.9s - 1211.1s]: a lot of work to get that. And there's a lot embodied in that one merit badge that you got, which is

[1211.1s - 1216.7s]: the Eagle Scout badge. And so the farmer said, can't I have one seal that says I do it all?

[1217.3s - 1220.8s]: Everything that's important to people on this planet in terms of their health or the climate

[1220.8s - 1225.9s]: or the environment, I do it. And I do it really well. Can I get a seal that sets a high bar

[1225.9s - 1230.2s]: standard? That means I do that. We think you can. We think you should and we're developing that.

[1230.8s - 1235.6s]: Now, art are certainly our goal with creating this standard, which is called the regenerative

[1235.6s - 1241.2s]: organic certification or ROC, the ROC seal, which will be rolling out in supermarkets in the next

[1241.2s - 1248.8s]: few months. Our goal is not to be the 1% of the 1%. Our goal is to set a high bar standard that

[1248.8s - 1257.2s]: leads everybody in the industry to the next level of production. People follow leaders and they follow

[1257.2s - 1262.4s]: groups that move in a positive direction. And nobody wants to be left behind and said, yeah,

[1262.4s - 1268.4s]: I'm going to do it the old way. There's no cars that get made today with drum brakes. They all

[1268.4s - 1274.4s]: have disc brakes because it's such a much better mode of stopping a vehicle. I mean, you get a bicycle

[1274.4s - 1278.8s]: that has disc brakes on it now, not the old little rubber things. It's got disc brakes. Perfect.

[1279.1s - 1285.3s]: It works. So everybody wants to move to that next level. And we understand that there aren't any

[1285.3s - 1290.9s]: farmers, even in the conventional model, who are deliberately trying to mismanage their soil.

[1290.9s - 1295.4s]: But unfortunately, that's what's happening. And so what we want to do is encourage

[1296.9s - 1302.9s]: processors and producers to buy products that are produced under the regenerative organic seal.

[1303.4s - 1309.2s]: And that way, we know that the labor on the farm was treated fairly. We know, and the farm could be

[1309.2s - 1316.0s]: international. This is an international certification, not just domestic certification. So people who

[1316.0s - 1322.2s]: are buying a food product that came from India or Argentina or any other country in the world,

[1322.4s - 1327.0s]: you'd like to know that the people who produced that food, who processed that food were treated

[1327.0s - 1332.6s]: fairly or that fiber, a fiber product that were treated fairly. Any animals that were involved in

[1332.6s - 1338.7s]: the system were treated fairly and that the soil is improving with time. So whether we sequester

[1338.7s - 1345.0s]: carbon in India or in Indiana, it's all the same to the planet. We just got to drag that carbon

[1345.0s - 1350.0s]: out of the atmosphere and get it in the soil. And this regenerative model actually does that.

[1350.4s - 1355.9s]: Yeah, it's absolutely beautiful. It's a race to the top, right? Instead of a race to the bottom.

[1356.7s - 1363.6s]: Yeah, yeah, it's so potent. What are some of the brands that you're excited about that we,

[1363.8s - 1368.5s]: as consumers, will be able to buy here in the coming months?

[1369.9s - 1375.5s]: Well, I would encourage all of your listeners and viewers to go to the regenerative organic alliance

[1375.5s - 1381.3s]: and check out the brands that have signed along with us. It's changing daily, so I don't want to

[1381.3s - 1386.9s]: leave anybody out when I call out specific brands. But two of the leading brands that have been

[1386.9s - 1392.2s]: involved with Rodeo from the very beginning and have taken a real leadership role are Dr.

segments.text: Welcome to the YONN Earth Community Podcast.
Today we are visiting with Jeff Moyer, the CEO of Rodal Institute.
Hi Jeff.
Hi Aaron, how are you today?
I'm doing great.
How are you doing?
Good.
It's much to be here.
Well I'm really excited for our conversation.
I know we've got a lot to cover for our audience and before we dive in let me tell them a little
about you and your background.
Jeff Moyer is the Chief Executive Officer of Rodal Institute and has been on staff at
Rodal Institute for over 44 years.
He spent over 30 years as a farm manager director, was appointed as Executive Director of the
Institute in September of 2015 and became CEO in September of 2019.
Jeff was project leader on the highly acclaimed organic no-till project and is the author of
the book on this subject called Organic No-till Farming, advancing no-till agriculture crops
soil equipment.
He is a past chair of the National Organic Standards Board and currently sits on the
boards of Regenerative Organic Alliance as Board Chair and the Soil Health Institute.
Jeff is a founding board member of Pennsylvania Certified Organic and past founder and board
chair of the Seed Farm, a new farmer incubator project.
So Jeff, wow, just an amazing career that you've had already thus far and I know you have
a really important perspective to share with our audience and we're going to talk there
today.
We're going to get dirty here.
So let's just dive right in and then want to ask you what's the big deal?
What's the big deal about soil and regeneration?
What does this even matter?
Wow, the whole idea of regenerating the health of the soil is key to our survival as a human
species.
You know, we have to go back in time a little bit to really get into the ground and dig
up the dirt on regeneration and what we're talking about.
Our founder, J.I. Rodeil, way back in 1942, he wrote some words on a blackboard.
He said, healthy soil equals healthy food equals healthy people.
So he was really, you know, I don't know if he was a visionary.
Some people say he was.
I don't know if he was a genius.
I don't know if he was just lucky.
It doesn't really matter.
You know, he stumbled on to something that has really captured the attention of people
as he began to tell us as farmers that our role was not to produce food and it wasn't
to manage the soil is to make people healthy.
Now the tools that we use are the soil and the food, but how we manage that, the end
goal has to be to make people healthy.
So he would say if the goal, for example, farmers is to kill weeds, then Roundup is a great
tool.
But if the goal is to make people healthy, it's a terrible tool.
There's no way you can use Roundup to make people healthy.
It just doesn't move you in the right direction.
So he began to look at and discuss this production paradigm that he called organic agriculture
and is sort of caught on, but it was moving relatively slowly.
His son Robert Rodeo took over the, the, the organic, I mean, the, the Rodeo enterprises
in 1971 when J.R. Rodeo passed away and he was a little frustrated with the speed at
which organic practices were being adopted.
So he was an early proponent of sort of giving the standard or creating a standard within
the federal government and working with the USDA.
Many people were upset then.
Many people are still upset, you know, 30 years later that that's what happened with
the word, but he saw it as an opportunity to move farther and faster because if you had
a word that is sanctioned by the USDA, certainly it carries a lot more penational marketplace
than things will move farther faster and they have.
But he was also pretty smart and he recognized that when you give something away, you lose
control.
So we lost control of the word and we gave up a lot of concepts that were originally
part of organic, for example, the idea of continuous improvement.
That kind of shelved early on in the conversations with the federal government because they wanted
to put our organic stand under their marketing division and how does an ag marketer certify
continuous improvement, you know, it just was too esoteric for a periodical for them to
dig grass.
So they put that off on the side.
There was always this idea of that organic was supposed to be good for the soil.
And so there's a little bit of language in the law about soil, but it's really not very strong.
There was always a concept in the organic farming community that dealt with animal welfare.
But the standards in our NLP program are relatively weak on animal welfare.
And then the organic standard, the way it's written today in our national NLP regulations,
national organic program regulations, there's no language all around human health or
social justice or any of those community kind of activist or activism components.
And so he was really interested in figuring out how do we magnify the word organic and make it
mean what it really should mean and embody all of those tools.
So he came up with the new word regeneration.
At the time he was talking about that, that was late 1970s, early 1980s.
He was talking about regenerative agriculture and everybody sort of poo pooed that idea and said,
no, we're going to really gravitate towards this word sustainable and sustainability.
The problem with the word sustainability and that's never been a rodeo word.
It's a relatively weak word.
It's not a strong action word.
Now, it's a simple word to understand because people understand what sustain means.
But you can sustain a bad system with enough inputs.
And some systems and some processes really should not be sustained because that's not what we
want to do. So if somebody said, how is your life and you said, oh, it's sustainable,
they'd be kind of sad or how is your relationship with your spouse or your significant other and you
said, oh, it's sustainable. Yeah, just like you're smiling and I am too, people chop on
go, yeah, that's not a good word. I don't want to sustain it. And if you talk to people in the
international community, particularly people that are struggling financially or struggling with
their farm operation because they don't have enough inputs to do what they want to do,
or don't have access to markets. And you say, how would you like to sustain what you have?
They said, no, we want to improve it. So he's looking for a word that showcased this concept of
improvement, continuous improvement, and he latched onto the word regenerative. And to me,
it makes a lot of sense. What we've done now at Road Hill Institute in working with some major
brand partners is we've linked those two words together. And so now we talk about regenerative
organic certification, regenerative organic, freefaring practices, because we really believe that
organic is a baseline by which we really should be farming to get the chemistry and the synthetic
chemicals out of our food production system. Going back to that original paradigm, trying to make
people healthy, we've got to get those chemicals out of the system. And then we can launch from
there into a regenerative model where we really do include animal welfare, social justice,
and then of course, focusing on healthy soil. Absolutely. Yeah, that is such an important and
central discussion that affects all of us. And one of the things I noticed when we're doing the
Y on Earth work and events all around the country is that a lot of folks still have this impression
that organic agriculture somehow does a new thing or even a fat or some sort of marketing
invention. And so I often have a lot of fun on a stage going clear to one end and saying let's
create a timeline and start maybe with the Egyptian empire and walk our way back through a few
thousand years of history, all of which basically was organic agriculture right up until about a
century ago. And what I think is so important for folks to understand, to really understand,
is that this chemical and synthetic form of agriculture is the aberration. It is the
thing that is absolutely outside of the norm of how we ordinarily tend to do agriculture as a species.
And I wonder if you come into that sort of encounter with folks, you know, not really understanding
the context the way it needs to be understood. Well, we certainly we do. I would say that the timeline
that you defined is exactly correct. The current industrial agricultural model that we have in place,
not just the United States but globally around the world is a relatively new phenomenon
that was really designed around this concept that what we need to do is focus all of our energy
on tons of output. We focus very little on true quality. Now every farmer wants to produce a
quality product and I'm not suggesting they don't want to do that. But the measuring stick by which
we judge success on farms or that we incentivize farmers to operate is based on yield.
It's a little dissonuous to suggest that the true sum of our of our ability to survive on the
planet comes down to tons and tons of commodities. Obviously we have to produce food because we have
billions of people to feed and I'm not suggesting that that's not important. But it's not the sole
measuring stick. We should not say, well, farmers are judged only on their ability to produce tons and
tons of this yellow stuff that we call corn and they don't even see it as producing food. Most of
the farmers across the Midwestern part of the United States don't really see themselves as food
producers. They're commodity growers. They grow commodities of corn and beans. The corn could be
used for ethanol. It could go. There's probably corn in this vast. I have no idea. There's corn and
soy beans in everything. And so they don't really see themselves as food producers. Well, when we
separate the concept of agriculture from food production, we've disincentivized farmers from
paying attention to what their real goal is. And then at the same time, what we've done is we've
said we're willing to sacrifice our soil and our environment and our ecology for the sake of that
yield. So it doesn't matter what you do to the soil. Farmers aren't judged on that. Do whatever
you have to do. Get as many tons as you can, produce them as cheaply as you can, and try to survive
on the margins. And that's really an unfair system. Farmers have always done what we've asked
them to do. And unfortunately, we've asked them to do the wrong thing. Now, where I disagree with
the timeline is that when we look at organic agriculture or regenerative organic agriculture today,
what we do look at the past to see what farmers did that was good, we've also modernized it.
So when we pay attention to modern engineering, we pay attention to modern biology. So we're using
good plant genetics. We're not suggesting that what we do is go back in time and put a few million
bison on the great plains for a few people who come out there to manage them and say that's organic
agriculture, that's where we should head. That's not the direction we're heading. We're going to
take advantage of precision agriculture. We're going to take advantage of robotics. We're going to
take advantage of all the tools that are at our disposal. So long as they don't interfere with
our ability to make people healthy. So those tools that we've incorporated in agriculture that don't
lend themselves to human health, we're going to sit on the shelf and say they no longer have a
role to play in food production. It's more fiber production because they're destroying the soil,
they're destroying the animals and the biodiversity on that, that live in that environment and
ecology. And then we're also unfortunately making ourselves sick. And that's kind of where we're
stocking. We understand that there's big business that's pushing the current model. And there's a
lot of incentive out there in the business world to keep the status quo going. Change is expensive,
change is difficult. Even positive change can be challenging and difficult. We understand that. You
graduate from high school, you go to college, positive change, still struggle, there's tension,
we understand that. You're single, you get married, tension. We understand that. It's a positive
change. Well, the same thing happens when you move from a chemical-based system to an organic system.
There's stresses in there. What we need to do now is a society is figure out, certainly we
